item.title: How I got started with blogdown
item.description: The first thing to notice after you follow Yihui’s instructions from the beginning to section 1.2 is that the generic config.toml is the same as the one in exampleSite. You can do that in the Bash shell with diff, which returns nothing if the two files are identical: diff config.toml themes/hugo-lithium-theme/exampleSite/config.toml So if you’re going to experiment with different themes, it’s probably best to do it now before you go down too deep into modifying config.

item.title: How about MathJax?
item.description: The default Lithium theme in blogdown comes with MathJax support. This big Sigma here – \(\Sigma\) – will show like the Greek upper case Sigma if you have it and as dollar sign, backslash, Sigma, dollar sign if you don’t. This seems driven by a script called math-code.js here: library('here') ## here() starts at /Users/ghuiber/heywhatshere dir(file.path(here(), 'themes/hugo-lithium-theme/static/js')) ## [1] "math-code.js" dir(file.path(here(), 'themes/ghostwriter/static/js')) ## [1] "jquery-1.11.3.min.js" "jquery.fitvids.js" "math-code.js" ## [4] "scripts.js" dir(file.

item.title: A Plain Markdown Post
item.description: This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are: You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r}); A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc. There are many differences in syntax between Blackfriday’s Markdown and Pandoc’s Markdown.

item.title: About
item.description: This is a “hello world” example website for the blogdown package. The theme was forked from @jrutheiser/hugo-lithium-theme and modified by Yihui Xie.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.
